word.description:
{烏龍} is *black dragon*, and {茶} is [tea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tea), so {烏龍茶} is *black dragon tea*.

**Pronunciation*

[Oolong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oolong) ({烏龍} wu lùhng) rhymes with the name of the peninsula area of Hong Kong, [Kowloon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kowloon) ({九龍} gáu lùhng). That second character {龍} is also the first character for lobster ({龍蝦} lùhng hā), *dragon shrimp*.

**Origin Stories**

There are a few origin stories for the name (literally *black dragon*). One is that oolong tea evolved from a Dragon-Phoenix tribute tea and later renamed Black Dragon. Another theory for the name is that oolong tea first existed in the Wuyi Mountains region. Another story is that the tea was discovered by a man named Wu Liang, who accidentally let the tea leaves ferment (after getting distracted by a deer).

images.place: New Asian BBQ, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: [Oolong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oolong), the Mandarin pronunciation (also similar to the Cantonese pronunciation), is a brown tea with slightly fermented leaves and moderate caffeine content (less than that of black tea but more than green tea).

word.description: {翠} is *blue-green* and {玉} is *jade*, {烏龍} is *oolong* or literally *black dragon*. So 翠玉烏龍 is *blue-green jade black dragon*.

images.place: Tea Zaanti, Salt Lake City, Utah

description: This is a light oolong tea from Taiwan.

word.description: {奶} is *milk*, and {香} is *fragrant*, so {奶香} is *milk fragrant*.

description:
Not to be confused with [milk tea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milk_tea), which is tea with milk added, milk oolong tea is an [oolong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oolong) tea that has a naturally milky taste.

**Origin**

This specific variety of oolong originated in Taiwan and is named 金萱 ([Jin Xuan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jin_Xuan_tea) in Mandarin, literally Golden Daylily), but sometimes the term *milk oolong* is more broadly applied to other varieties of oolong or even those with milk-flavored additives.

word.description: 包種 is *wrapped kind*, referring to the traditional method of wrapping the leaves in paper during the drying process.

description: [Baozhong tea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozhong_tea) is a lightly oxidized tea, between green and [oolong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oolong) teas (usually classified as oolong), often listed as *pouchong tea*.

word.description: 大 is *big*, 紅 is *red*, and 袍 is *gown*, so {大紅袍} is *big red gown*. Legend has it that this tea was administered by a monk to an ailing scholar who similarly revived the emporer with the tea and was rewarded with a big red gown (monk got nothing).

images.place: R and F Market, South Salt Lake, Utah

description: [da hong pao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Da_Hong_Pao), the Mandarin pronunciation of this tea, is a traditionally expensive [Wuyi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wuyi_tea) oolong tea (but affordable if you buy the ones that aren't from the original da hong pao trees).

word.description: {四季} is *four seasons* ({四} is *four* and {季} is *season*). {春} is *spring* (the season), so {四季春} is *four seasons spring*, alluding to its year-round harvest quality.

description: Four seasons oolong, also known by its Mandarin pronunciation Si Ji Chun, is an [oolong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oolong) tea developed in Taiwan and now also grown in Thailand and Vietnam.
